image.altText: a large group of workers in high-vis shirts marching through brisbane city

items.synopsis: Workers are rallying in Brisbane amid investigations into a serious accident at a Cross River Rail construction site, calling for safety concerns to be resolved before they return to work.

title.children: Workers stage protest after man critically injured in Cross River Rail construction site fall

image.altText: A bald man in black tshirt and woman with long dark hair and grey jumper work in a drycleaning facility surrounded by machinery.

items.synopsis: Inflation has slowed down again, with consumer prices up 6 per cent over the year to June, below most economists' forecasts and reducing the chance of an RBA rate rise next week.

title.children: Interest rate rise now unlikely next week after inflation comes in below forecasts

image.altText: Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis side-by-side with his brain scan

items.synopsis: The effect of head knocks over Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis's decades-long sporting career isn’t immediately obvious. That is, until you see what’s happening to his brain.

title.children: From the age of 4, Gordi played contact sports. See how it has impacted his brain

image.altText: Le Smileys childcare centre

items.synopsis: A childcare boss's decision after learning two of her staff had left a three-year-old on a bus in central Queensland for several hours has been credited with saving the girl's life.

title.children: Tears as women who left child on daycare bus sentenced over 'nightmare situation'

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: Police say 31-year-old Mahmoud Abbas was shot by an unknown man outside a property in Greenacre this morning.

title.children: Sydney criminal defence lawyer shot outside home in what police say was targeted attack

image.altText: A group of volunteers surrounded by stranded pilot whales

items.synopsis: Authorities are urging the public to stay clear as they work to save the lives of the remaining 46 pilot whales stranded on Cheynes Beach.

title.children: 'Devastating': 51 whales dead on WA beach as difficult rescue effort continues

image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

items.synopsis: Consumer inflation for the June quarter falls more than expected by economists, while the IMF warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation falls to 6 per cent as interest rate hikes dampen demand, ASX surges, IMF warns of economic challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What prices are driving services inflation? This graph from the ABS shows how the prices of selected services have behaved over the last 12 months. Starting from the left-hand side, prices have been falling for: Veterinary and other pet services (since December) Restaurant meals (since the March quarter) Maintenance & repair of dwelling (since the March quarter) But prices have been rising noticeably for: Rents (continuously for the last 12 months) Hairdressing & personal grooming services (continuously for the last 12 months) Insurance (rising continuously and exceptionally quickly since June last year) Financial services (continuously for the last 12 months) So, when you add them together, the pace of inflation in the prices of services is still increasing overall.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A further breakdown of services inflation

children.content: What prices are driving services inflation?
This graph from the ABS shows how the prices of selected services have behaved over the last 12 months.
Starting from the left-hand side, prices have been
falling
for:
Veterinary and other pet services (since December)
Restaurant meals (since the March quarter)
Maintenance
repair of dwelling (since the March quarter)
But prices have been
rising noticeably
for:
Rents (continuously for the last 12 months)
Hairdressing
personal grooming services (continuously for the last 12 months)
Insurance (rising continuously and exceptionally quickly since June last year)
Financial services (continuously for the last 12 months)
So, when you add them together, the pace of inflation in the prices of services is still increasing overall.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Investors have reacted quickly to the bigger-than-expected drop in inflation over the June quarter. The odds of a rate hike by the Reserve Bank next week have dropped, with the market betting on a 29 per cent chance of a 0.25 per cent rise, and a 71 per cent chance that rates will stay on hold. The Australian dollar slumped and the Australian market increased to a five-month high. The dollar fell nearly 1 per cent to 67.29 US cents because investors think the pull back in inflation buys the RBA more time to consider how the economy is tracking before it pulls the rate lever again. Rate hikes boost currencies because they increase the cost of money. The ASX 200 extended its gains by 0.8 per cent with investors also betting on a pause, although real estate firms are lower. Consumer staples did well on the news, but it's banks and big miners that are driving the market today. Banks extended their gains after the numbers came out. ANZ is up 1.5 per cent, while Westpac has put on 1.6 per cent. Even though banks make money from interest rate rises, higher borrowing costs also mean a likely rise in loan defaults.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investors see RBA pause

children.content: Investors have reacted quickly to the bigger-than-expected drop in inflation over the June quarter.
The odds of a rate hike by the Reserve Bank next week have dropped, with the market betting on a 29 per cent chance of a 0.25 per cent rise, and a 71 per cent chance that rates will stay on hold.
The Australian dollar slumped and the Australian market increased to a five-month high.

The dollar fell nearly 1 per cent to 67.29 US cents because investors think the pull back in inflation buys the RBA more time to consider how the economy is tracking before it pulls the rate lever again.
Rate hikes boost currencies because they increase the cost of money.
The ASX 200
extended its gains by 0.8 per cent with investors also betting on a pause, although real estate firms are lower.
Consumer staples did well on the news, but it's banks and big miners that are driving the market today.
Banks extended their gains after the numbers came out.
ANZ is up 1.5 per cent, while Westpac has put on 1.6 per cent.
Even though banks make money from interest rate rises, higher borrowing costs also mean a likely rise in loan defaults.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's dig a little deeper now. We've seen the headline rate : the annual pace of inflation has fallen from 7.8 per cent in the December quarter, to 7 per cent in the March quarter, now to 6 per cent in the June quarter. But underneath that headline figure, we can break it apart to look at what's happening to prices for "goods" on one hand, and "services" on the other. And there's a lot of divergence there, which this graph shows. The Bureau of Statistics says inflation in the prices for "services" has just recorded its largest annual rise since 2001, driven by higher prices in a range of services categories including rents, restaurant meals, holiday travel and insurance. Services inflation is now running at 6.3 per cent, up from 6.1 per cent in the March quarter. So, it's still heading higher. But "goods" inflation is definitely heading down. It's running at an annual pace of 5.8 per cent, down from 7.6 per cent in the March quarter, so that's a significant decline. The ABS says price rises for food, furniture, appliances and clothes slowed in the June quarter, while automotive fuel prices were 3.6 per cent lower compared to 12 months ago.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Goods inflation falling, but services inflation still gathering pace

children.content: Let's dig a little deeper now.
We've seen the
headline rate
: the annual pace of inflation has fallen from 7.8 per cent in the December quarter, to 7 per cent in the March quarter, now to 6 per cent in the June quarter.
But underneath that headline figure, we can break it apart to look at what's happening to prices for "goods" on one hand, and "services" on the other.
And there's a lot of divergence there, which this graph shows.

The Bureau of Statistics says inflation in the prices for "services" has just recorded its largest annual rise since 2001, driven by higher prices in a range of services categories including rents, restaurant meals, holiday travel and insurance.
Services inflation is now running at 6.3 per cent, up from 6.1 per cent in the March quarter.
So, it's still heading higher.
But "goods" inflation is definitely heading down.
It's running at an
annual pace of 5.8 per cent
, down from 7.6 per cent in the March quarter, so that's a significant decline.
The ABS says price rises for food, furniture, appliances and clothes slowed in the June quarter, while automotive fuel prices were 3.6 per cent lower compared to 12 months ago.

image.altText: Photograph outside the Australian Tax Office headquarters

items.synopsis: Following an ABC Investigation, the Australian Tax Office admits criminals have fraudulently claimed more than $557 million from the Commonwealth using an identity loophole.

title.children: ATO admits identity loophole exposed by the ABC tops half a billion dollars

image.altText: A building site with green signage

items.synopsis: Queensland's building regulator has suspended the licence of large-scale high-rise builder GCB Constructions after it allegedly failed to pay debts and comply with financial monitoring.

title.children: Major Gold Coast construction company ordered to stop work as licence suspended

image.altText: Geoff and Rhonda doing a puzzle.

items.synopsis: Geoff is selectively mute and has a fragile X syndrome. When his mother engaged a disability service to take him to work, she didn't know it would use up almost all his NDIS funding.

title.children: Geoff was driven to work three days a week. He received a $700 invoice for it

image.altText: A female footballer in a gold Australia jersey smiles and celebrates with her arm extended, celebrating a goal

items.synopsis: With Sam Kerr already on the sidelines, the Matildas lose Mary Fowler ahead of their clash with Nigeria in Brisbane.

title.children: Matildas lose another attacking weapon in crucial World Cup clash with Nigeria

image.altText: A close up of a man speaking while gesturing with his hand

items.synopsis: The announcement comes after the ABC obtained vision showing multiple greyhounds, including puppies, apparently being kicked and punched by a person on a property south-east of Adelaide.

image.altText: Timothy Shea stands outside the glass doors of Manhattan federal court.

items.synopsis: A Colorado businessman receives the longest prison sentenced yet imposed over a fraudulent scheme to raise money for Donald Trump's border wall.

title.children: A non-profit raised millions for Trump's border wall. Here's why a third man behind the campaign has been sentenced

image.altText: A man wearing a mask

items.synopsis: Damien Wanstall, who previously taught maths at Kellyville High School, was unaware the person he was engaging with online in 2020 was actually an undercover police officer and was arrested when he arranged to meet.

title.children: Former Sydney deputy principal jailed for trying to meet fictitious 14-year-old girl for sex

image.altText: A school zone sign in front of a tree

items.synopsis: After six months and two school terms, the Queensland government has confirmed the cameras have not resulted in a single fine for speeding motorists.

title.children: No fines issued since school zone speed cameras switched on due to 'technical issues'

image.altText: a large aboriginal flag flying above a large group of people at a city march

items.synopsis: State and territory governments are not being held accountable for failing to meet Closing the Gap targets and in some cases are actively exacerbating disadvantage, a Productivity Commission report finds.

title.children: 'Another broken promise to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people': Report warns of continued disadvantage

image.altText: Metro West sign

items.synopsis: The offer comes after NSW Premier Chris Minns repeatedly refused to guarantee the underground line will go ahead.

title.children: Developers offer to help bankroll Metro West line, if they can build additional homes

image.altText: A red up arrow next to a percentage sign on top of an aerial view of dozens of houses.

items.synopsis: The level of mortgage arrears is creeping higher and the number of borrowers at risk of mortgage stress is at its highest level since 2008.

title.children: Nearly a million borrowers are 'extremely at risk' of mortgage stress, but very few are defaulting yet

image.altText: A smiling young woman takes a selfie. A man, whose face is blurred, sits beside her.

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court jury has been asked by the Crown to put illegal drug use aside as it deliberates over the fate of Danielle Easey's accused killer.

title.children: Jurors asked to put Danielle Easey's lifestyle 'to one side' as end of murder trial looms

image.altText: A man with long hair and a green cap looks at the camera with trees behind him

items.synopsis: Police have abandoned a search for the 22-year-old man who went missing in rugged terrain on Magnetic Island more than a year ago.

title.children: Search for young Magnetic Island man called off

image.altText: Meta logo in background in focus with blurry silhouette heads in foreground.

items.synopsis: The Federal Court hears Meta used a free security app promoted as protecting data but the tech giant used it to find out "nearly everything" users were doing on their devices.

title.children: Free security app 'knows nearly everything' about users, court told as Facebook owners Meta fined $20m

image.altText: Composite image of young girl and police members and a search dog.

items.synopsis: The largest-ever police search ever undertaken in northern Tasmania is underway, with a new area of bushland being scoured for signs of missing teen Shyanne-Lee Tatnell.

title.children: Massive bushland search underway for missing Tasmanian teen Shyanne-Lee

image.altText: Man poses in front of blue background wearing suit

items.synopsis: Carlos Macci, 72, sold fatal fentanyl-laced heroin to actor Michael K Williams, who was best known for playing Omar Little in the HBO show.

title.children: 72yo drug dealer jailed for selling deadly heroin batch to Wire star

image.altText: A jockey in red, white and blue silks rides a camel at high speed, with feet in stirrups, strop in hand and hair flying.

items.synopsis: She's best known as a travelling tent boxer with leg hairs so sharp "they could spear a rat" but Beaver Brophy, who has a CV that reads like a handful of darts thrown at a careers handbook, has added a bizarre new skill to her list of qualifications.

title.children: Travelling tent boxer Beaver Brophy becomes camel racing champion in Queensland outback

image.altText: A woman's hands type on a laptop keyboard.

items.synopsis: A Byron Bay woman's $1.8m legal nightmare highlights how hackers use username and password combinations leaked online to access other accounts, a scam on the rise due to recent major data breaches, experts warn.

title.children: Never heard of 'credential stuffing' cyber attacks? It's just one way scammers use your details gained from a data breach

image.altText: A graphic showing a confused person looking at different plastics.

items.synopsis: Do you know your PP from your HDPE, and your PVC from your soft plastics? Plastic recycling is a minefield, so here's how to tell what you're dealing with and which bin you should put it in.

title.children: Plastic not so fantastic: Do you know which numbers can't be recycled?

image.altText: A logo that says "Groupe Lactalis" on the facade of an industrial-looking building.

items.synopsis: It is the first time the ACCC has fought a dairy company in court over bargaining power imbalances.

title.children: Owner of some of Australia's biggest dairy brands fined $950K over treatment of farmers

image.altText: David Pass sits in the in Queensland Health's Forensic and Scientific Services lab, boxes of vapes stand nearby

items.synopsis: Impounded vapes are being tested for polonium-210, a radioisotope which naturally occurs in cigarette tobacco.

title.children: Scientists suspect vapes contain 'weapon of espionage' polonium-210 after finding cancer-causing substances

image.altText: An elderly man with a white beard looks stern.

items.synopsis: Bunbury resident Bob Barber says he and his wife would be "starving" without food support from organisations like Doors Wide Open and Foodbank.

title.children: This grandfather worked his whole life. Now he can't afford to buy groceries

image.altText: A composite image of the hospital lit up at night, and a man with a guide dog sitting on a bench.

items.synopsis: A court ordered improvements for people who are blind or have visual impairments in 2021. But an advocate for the family of Peter Ryan — who died before the ruling — says the changes have been slow and "frustrating".

title.children: Blind man's family considering further legal action against Sunshine Coast hospital

image.altText: Ten women of varying ages and walks of life gather together and smile out the front of a courthouse

items.synopsis: Robert Hadden abused trusting and vulnerable patients for years and will serve the maximum sentence for the offences, which a judge described as "horrific".

title.children: Former US gynaecologist jailed for 20 years for molesting patients

image.altText: two men at night stood near a bus station smiling at camera

items.synopsis: It's a different way to tackle youth crime in a state with a rising young offender arrest rate, and a suite of new tough-on-crime laws.

title.children: 'Call us, we're happy to come get you': See what it's like on a ride-along with a different kind of police patrol
